page.title: 11Castle Remains, Yelden
page.content: The Castle provides an interesting feature within the village. There is some degree of uncertainty as to it's date and origin. The Castle is believed to have been occupied in the 1st Century by the Iceni, a tribe of Britains from the East of England. It occupies some 14 acres of land alongside the River Till. The works comprise a central keep or mound, 40 ft. high from the bottom of the moat and on the north side 2 baileys. A wide moat still holding water in winter surrounds the south bailey. There has probably been fire damage as there is evidence of reddened stone. In 12th Century a stone castle was built on the mound, it was owned by the Earl of Gloucester and sub let to the Trailly Family. Today public footpaths near to the castle make cursory inspection interesting.
